results.headline: Mr. Frost, Meet Mr. Nixon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frost/Nixon

results.summary_short: It’s twinkle versus glower in the big-screen edition of Peter Morgan’s theatrical smackdown “Frost/Nixon.”

results.headline: Got Their Musical Mojo Working

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cadillac Records

results.summary_short: “Cadillac Records” is a rollicking and insightful celebration of Chicago blues in its hectic golden age.

results.headline: Kidnapping, Suicide and Other Family Matters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nobel Son

results.summary_short: “Nobel Son” is an aggressively noisy exercise in style over substance about nasty people doing nasty things to one another in (sigh) Southern California.

results.headline: Two Lives After Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ciao

results.summary_short: Deeply sincere and exceedingly slow even at 87 minutes, “Ciao” involves two strangers who become acquaintances after the death of a mutual friend.

results.headline: Young New Yorkers With Old Ideas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let Them Chirp Awhile

results.summary_short: “Let Them Chirp Awhile” is a painfully unsympathetic take on postcollegiate New Yorkers who think themselves artists but don’t have an original thought in their heads.

results.headline: A Comic-Book Avenger Strikes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Punisher: War Zone

results.summary_short: You will see “Punisher: War Zone” or not, and it will make about as much sense to you either way.

results.headline: Autistic Son Reveals Family Shame and Strength

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Black Balloon

results.summary_short: Would you be able to cope? That is the challenge laid down by “The Black Balloon,” a portrait of a middle-class Australian family whose oldest son has severe autism.

results.headline: Awe, Revulsion and Affection for Those Particles Unto Which Thou Shalt Return

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dust

results.summary_short: “Dust” is an eccentric and profoundly informative documentary.

results.headline: When Laws and Liberties Test Each Other’s Limits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The End of America

results.summary_short: “The End of America” is an unsettling documentary polemic about the erosion of civil liberties in the wake of 9/11.

results.headline: Lust and Disaffection in Tel Aviv

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antarctica

results.summary_short: As promised by its frigid title, “Antarctica” serves up gay life in Tel Aviv as a frozen wasteland of casual hookups and emotional vacancy.

results.headline: Freedom Fighter in Life Becomes Potent Symbol in Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Milk

results.summary_short: Harvey Milk was an intriguing, inspiring figure. And “Milk” is a marvel.

results.headline: When Faith Meets Feminism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secrets

results.summary_short: “The Secrets” is a religious soap opera and feminist cri de coeur.

results.headline: Clothes Make the Man, and Sometimes Improve His Fight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transporter 3

results.summary_short: To chart the differences between “Transporter 3” and its two predecessors is as pointless as trying to parse its flimsy plot.

results.headline: Two Unmerrymakers in a Grueling Land of Social Awfulness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Christmases

results.summary_short: “Four Christmases” is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup of the season.

results.headline: Oh Give Me a Home Where the Cowboys and Kangaroos Roam

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Australia

results.summary_short: “Australia” is a pastiche of genres and references wrapped up into one horse-galloping, cattle-stampeding, camera-swooping, music-swelling, widescreen package.

results.headline: Puck’s Love Potion, Splashed Across Town

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Were the World Mine

results.summary_short: “Were the World Mine,” an indie alternative to Disney’s “High School Musical” franchise, is a small, endearing film.

results.headline: Going Bonkers, Superhero Style

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Special

results.summary_short: “Special” puts an indie spin on the current Hollywood vogue for moody superhero psychodrama.

results.headline: The Love That Dare Not Bare Its Fangs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Twilight

results.summary_short: It’s love at first look instead of first bite in “Twilight,” a deeply sincere, outright goofy vampire romance for the hot-not-to-trot abstinence set.

results.headline: Love Beyond Boundaries

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Can't Think Straight

results.summary_short: Plugging the same two actresses into different Sapphic scenarios may be a valid filmmaking strategy but it can be an extremely boring one.

results.headline: Suds, Southern Scenery and Fistfuls of Weaponry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lake City

results.summary_short: When Sissy Spacek speaks her clichéd lines in the mediocre screenplay of “Lake City,” her delivery lends them a resonance that is not in the written words.
